choices: Millicent Fenwick, A Lady Whose Age Shall Not Be Discussed
Archibald Preston, A Man of Experience and Accomplishment
Penelope, A Young Woman In Her Twenties.
Reggie, A Young Man In His Twenties.
1.content:
Our adventure sets forth from the Center of the Empire, the Shining Jewel on the Thames. Shining in the metaphorical sense, that is. Between the fog and the coal smoke, not too much literally shines around here, except the gaslights fighting to illuminate the streets.

We meet our hero(ine) in the early evening among the docks of the Port of London. If you may, kind sir or madam, select that character whose adventure you wish to experience...

1. Millicent Fenwick, A Lady Whose Age Shall Not Be Discussed
2. Archibald Preston, A Man of Experience and Accomplishment
3. Penelope, A Young Woman In Her Twenties.
4. Reggie, A Young Man In His Twenties.
5. A Teen Boy or Girl

(Make your selection after the Notes section.)

--------------------------------


Notes:
The history of the world up to the beginning of the Edwardian age is roughly the same as what you may have learned in school, but with a few significant deviations.

First, for whatever reason, Mr. Edison has not been the success he was in our history. He did have a touch of success with the phonograph, but that's about it. The dynamo, the electric light, and the cinema are all as yet uninvented.

Second, Mr. Otto's internal combustion engine is distinctly missing. The world is proceeding on a steam-powered basis. But steam, it seems, is capable of all kinds of things you didn't know about.

In addition, there are a few odd deviations in geopolitik to discuss:
(I specifically added some powerful non-white nations in the alternative history to improve the feasibility of non-white characters. They will still likely face disrespect in caucasian nations, but perhaps there will be more balancing factors for them.)

The US and Canada are more or less the same as in the history you learned, except Texas never joined the Union. Brazil and Mexico both have emperors and aristocracy. Mexico is a long-time rival with the U.S. for influence in Texas, Central America and the Caribbean, while Brazil, Argentina and Chile have fought several wars, trading possession of Uruguay, Paraguay and Patagonia several times.

The Zulu Empire was able to deal the Brits a somewhat embarrassing defeat and have since grown to dominate the southern quarter of Africa, except about half of South Africa that the Brits have held onto. The Jolof Empire, which held onto its historic extent,is locked in an eternal power struggle with The Kingdom of Morocco for control of West Africa. The Ethiopian Empire is a power in East Africa counterbalancing British-controlled Egypt and Sudan. The remainder of the continent is under European or Ottoman domination.

In Asia, China is the same mess as in your history books, except with a little more success fighting back here and there. It has recently forced an end to the unequal treaties, but is still stuck with a number of European and Japanese colonies on its coastline. India is largely the same, except that a powerful khanate has appeared in Punjab and Afghanistan, threatening to challenge Britain for control of the subcontinent. Japan controls Manchuria and Korea as in mundane history.

In Europe, the biggest difference is the lack of a Prussian Empire. That means no Franco-Prussian war, no Kaiser, and a very different dynamic in Central Europe, which is a patchwork of Ruritanian duchies and kingdoms (as before the Prussians). Napoleon had his successes in Italy and Central Europe, but it was the Poles on the allied side instead of Russia.

Without the Prussians to participate in the Polish Partition, the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth survived and got back on its feet. Other than its portion of Polish territory, the Russian Empire is roughly the same, and as in mundane history has fought wars with Japan.

Any more odd details I or anyone else come up with will be added as they are created (provided I like them!)

Regarding a few terms: "Unwashed" characters are not literally failing to bathe; this term simply means the Great Unwashed, the working class, the street class and such.

Pirates in steampunk NEVER use ordinary ships. They use airships. Or submarines (think Captain Nemo). Or ships that somehow convert to land-going vehicles. Anything, as long as it does something more than merely float on the surface of the water.

Opportunists are treasure hunters, gold seekers, anyone looking to turn a (legal) buck.

Mercenary characters do dirty work for hire; they can be military mercenaries, but can be more. Legality is not so much a concern.

Tinker characters are not-yet-financially-successful inventors. They generally work as jacks of all trades, and mechanics extraordinaire.
1.title: And So It Begins...

choices: Lady of Unconventional Means (Can't call her a Rogue, after all. Hardly Polite.)
11.content:
A woman of Millicent's years would not ordinarily be seen after sunset strolling unescorted on East India Dock Road, but the sharp-eyed observer would recognize that Mrs. Fenwick was no ordinary dowager. Indeed, if for no other reason, one might deduce this from the Webley revolver held in a tastefully decorated holster hanging from a brass-buckled leather belt. After all, neither revolver, nor holster, nor leather belt would have been in an ordinary lady's wardrobe. In addition, one might observe that few ladies could hope to hang on to such a large caliber weapon were they to fire it.

A trio of street toughs who eyed her from the opposite side of the street chose not to inquire more closely, as did a few gentlemen seeking opportunities of varying sorts. Other eyes, however, made note of her approach, because they had prior dealings with Millicent Fenwick, the...
11.title: Millicent Fenwick, Lady of Undisclosed Age

111.content:
…lady of means.

Or at least, at first glance, she was the typical lady of means, a denizen of the British Empire's upper crust. Her bodice was of the finest brocade, and obviously lined with the finest leather and nearly unbreakable stays.

In point of fact, it was said (among those who had apparently known her for more years than she would admit to), that she was not only a crack shot with the revolver, but was also very skilled with the several blades she was known to carry. She hurried along her way, seemingly oblivious to all, but to the gentleman watching her from the darkness of the doorway, it was obvious she was totally aware of everything around her. She walked briskly along the road, closer and closer. He stood stock-still as she came on, hoping she would pass by, but his luck did not hold.

She stopped a mere 12 feet away. She placed her hand on the butt of the revolver and quietly said, "Jeremy, I know you were taught better than to skulk about, boy." He sighed as he stepped out into the halo of gaslight over the door. Perhaps the direct approach would be better after all, "Aunt Millicent, please don't tell mother I'm out this late, but could I follow you to the airship?" Millicent narrowed her eyes, "Why would you think I'm going to an airship, boy?" Jeremy looked down and shuffled his feet for a moment, then decided to just spill it. "Aunt Millicent," he said as he looked up to meet her gaze, "the whole family knows you come down here to the airship docks, and we just want to know what your are shipping or receiving that would come here this time of night."

She considered it for a moment, then stepped forward to her nephew. She looked up and down the road for a moment, then leaned forward, a gentle smile on her lips. "Jeremy," she said quietly, "Nobody has a need to know what I am shipping or receiving, but I'm somewhat fond of you. I will let you and you alone in on a secret if you promise not to tell." Jeremy gazed into her bright blue eyes and fully committed to the conspiracy, "Of course, Aunt Millicent," he crossed his heart with his right hand as he held his left up for her to see, "A secret is a bond, and you're my favorite aunt."

She leaned even closer, her bright eyes twinkling mischievously, "I don't care what's shipped on airships, as long as they pay well when they ship on MINE." Jeremy's eyes widened as he saw her grin. "Why, Aunt Millicent, you mean to say you're...
111.title: Lady of (Unconventional) Means

112.content:
At a dark shop door Millicent stopped and did a slow rotation, surveying the street and its occupants. Satisfied she pressed her back to the door and knocked softly. It opened a crack.

With a touch of impatience, she requested, "Gaylord, let me in. I have what you need."

Quickly the door swung wide and as quickly closed once Millicent slipped in. "Hurry," Gaylord urged, "Death is near, it seeks to tromp upon the light of my life, as we speak!"

Millicent swung the cloth bag from her back onto a scarred counter. "Twas a bit dicey getting this here. What with the Queen's ban on progressive electrical innovation and the poorness of your district." She worked the parcel open to reveal a small steam pot and a block of gadgetry that was about one foot square. A tangle of metal tubing and copper wire fell out when she tipped the bag over.

"How will this save us?" Gaylord looked over the pile suspiciously.

"This, my friend, is a miracle of our modern age; it steadies the patient's heart. It depends heavily on the work of Misters Edison and Tesla. I am calling it the Pace Setter. Come now, we must hurry, where is the patient?"

"Behind the stove where it is warm."

Following his direction Millicent looked behind the stove to find...
112.title: Lady Genius

choices: Dr. Loveless installed the Pace Setter with Gaylord and Millicent assisting.
Prognosis:  Dr Iverson and McGuilitty both doing well.
1121.content:
Note from the interactive owner: This chapter has the issue of not entirely making sense with respect to the prior chapters. I will be editing it to fit better, once I figure out what to do with it,

McGuilicutty, Gaylord's large poodle, freezing cold, covered in mud and smelly to boot, scurried behind the pot bellied stove. The dog was an intelligent animal, but he lacked what human-kind calls common sense. He hated himself about now. He couldn't just lick his body clean. He hovered in the corner, his entire body soaking wet. He shook himself repeatedly, trying to remove what was now crusted mud that was stuck to his curly fur. McGuilicutty had submerged himself in mud full of manure of some sort. No wonder the poodle smelled. Gaylord heard McGuilicutty whimpering.

Millicent was due any minute. She was bringing the Pace Setter package to steady the heart of the patient. Gaylord certainly did not expect to be encumbered with McGuilicutty's current dilemma. Gaylord needed to tend to Dr. Iverson, the patient lying behind the pot-bellied stove right next to the poodle. Dr. Iverson adored Gaylord's poodle under normal circumstances. The patient was falling in and out of consciousness. The more Gaylord smelled the manure and even felt chunks of it landing on his body, the more he suspected it must be covering the patient's body too. Dr. Iverson had a heart condition. Gaylord began to coolly react. "Millicent, call my assistant and have her remove this animal and get him cleaned up. You and I will care for Dr. Iverson. I will call Dr. Loveless and ask him to install the Pace Setter if he approves it for this case. He is familiar with this invention and recommends it. Keep the patient comfortable while I contact Dr. Loveless."

Gaylord reached Dr. Loveless momentarily. Gaylord had worked with Dr. Loveless for several years and was fairly certain of the procedure he would select.
1121.title: Cleaning of Gaylord's large Poodle, McGilicutty

12.content:
Archibald Preston, Archie to his closer acquaintances, was a familiar face on the Isle of Dogs. He frequented the pub on Glengall (which he was currently entering) because it was convenient to the wharves of Cubitt Town and to the Millwall Docks, not to mention the nearby train station. Transportation quickly and quietly arranged was quite important to Archie, since Scotland Yard often had occasion to seek him out.

Not that Mr. Preston was some common thief or street tough. Frankly he had rarely committed any crime at all within city limits. The Yard had other reasons to keep tabs on this...
12.title: Archibald Preston, Accomplished & Experienced Man

122.content:
The well respected professor Archibald Preston is bored...

Despise his immense intelligence and success with women, he's bored.

What could he do?

Take a walk in the notoriously criminal district of Radtown? There might be interesting encounters to be found.

Contact Inspector Grey? He might have some enigmatic work, something more challenging than the usual petty thefts.

Or travel? Worncall has always sounded intriguing. Its misty landscape, the blond beer and above all the rumors of weird religious communities.
122.title: Respected Professor

choices: Griffin says, "I must think about this before I decide."
123.content:
Archibald Preston entered the Three Hammers and was immediately met with a friendly call of, "Archie! Over here, old chap!" and the sight of his friend Griffin Lionfoot waving an arm.

"Hallo! Hallo!" Griffin said. "What brings the honorable Mister Preston out of the sun and into the shade? Be it only a matter of thirst? Or is an issue of consequence afoot?"

By then a pewter of beer had appeared before the good gentleman and he took a long quaff of it before answering. "Both, my friend! I shall be leaving London quite soon and journeying to the rain forests of South America!"

"Good heavens!" Griffin said. "What's the cause of this monumental change?"

"Funny you should use that word, Griff, because a monument is indeed involved. Professor Calamari has discovered the Temple of the Golden Chameleon."

"You don't say! He is already in country then?"

"Yes. He has been exploring in South America for nearly a year and now he wants me to help him enter the Temple of the Golden Chameleon. It's well-protected, you know, with countless booby traps."

Griffin rubbed his hands together. "What I wouldn't give to tackle all those locks and traps!"

"I was hoping that would be your attitude. You are welcome to join us. In fact, I urge you to join us. All expenses paid by the Institute, of course, plus a share of the treasure found, if any."

Griffin thought for a moment, then...
123.title: Archibald Preston, the Explorer's Story

1231.content:
A big grin appeared on Griffin Lionfoot's face. "Archie, my old friend, if I had a wife or a job or even a reasonably good chance of surviving another year in London on my dwindling finances, then I would have to think about it, but you caught me at just the right time. An expedition to South America with a chance for gold to be found is exactly what I need. I'm your man!"

Now it was Archie's turn to grin. "I am so happy, Griff! Your mechanical skills will be put to good use. I can sniff out a trapdoor or a spring-loaded arrow, but then I hardly know what to do about it. With you along we shall enter the Temple of the Golden Chameleon with little difficulty."

The two men shook hands on their agreement and only three days later they found themselves onboard the Queen Annabelle steaming their way down the Atlantic to Lisbon and from there to Belem in Brazil. The journey to Lisbon was smooth sailing, but the second leg of their journey was interrupted by an unusual event...
1231.title: Griffin Grins A Yes!

choices: Lady Penelope Martin, A Young Lady of Breeding
Dr. Penelope Brightside, Girl Genius (couldn’t resist, sorry!)
13.content:
No matter what, a girl in her early twenties had no business wandering about the dank wharves of London, and even more so as comely a maiden as young Penny. We’ll not speculate what reasons the many corrupt or worldly eyes watching her might have imagined she had, but we can say both her aplomb and her stiff upper lip served notice to them that they best keep their distance. It might be as well that the weapons accessorizing her wardrobe gave them pause, but we are sure, at least in Miss Penny’s mind, that the confidence she radiated was making all the difference.

So what sort of person is our heroine, Penelope? It seems she is...
13.title: Penelope, A Young Woman In Her Twenties.

choices: Penny ties up Kate and aided by the helmsman seizes control of the airship
Kate awakens to find Penny bent suspiciously over her with silken cords
Penny also falls into a drugged sleep as the helmsman enters cabin
131.content:
Lady Penelope did not so much wander as stroll purposefully, intent on her destination, and not distracted by the shadows moving along with her. Her upbringing had included a most thorough education. As a child she had learned Greek from a Spartan tutor. A quick study she had also absorbed the skills of African hunters and whilst on a short visit to Japan had gained some notoriety from being a mere female and yet being recognised for knowing the way of the warrior.

Her brief sojourn in Japan had been curtailed less she commit any serious offence to the Emperor who questioned the need for a young maiden to have such mastery of weapons. Her rapid departure, however, was due more to Scarlet Kate than to the vagaries of a senile Japanese Emperor. Kate had persuaded her that the best place to acquire a parasol to match her long blonde hair was on the island of Serendib. The island was far distant but the winds were favourable to a steamship that floated on the air.

Despite her varied education and extensive travels, Penelope had never been aboard a flying steam driven airship. Her journeys had never required that she ascend to the heavens. Not that she had never ascend to the heavens. Her experiments with her fathers steam powered Jaguar had on more than one occasion caused the vehicle to take to the air before the safety valves were able to activate the hydraulic emergency brakes. She had been fortunate in never suffering anything more serious than a torn blouse.

Her mother had been aghast at seeing the torn blouse and it took Penelope some time to reassure her that it was the corner of the windshield that had caught the garment and caused such damage. The chauffeur managed to keep his job at least on that occasion. He would never forget the Duchesses punishment and thanked God it had been curtailed before he felt the full force of her wrath. He did however, keep in mind the vision of the Duchess with her storm rigging in full flight and thought he might yet arouse her anger sufficiently to ride that storm.

Of the chauffeur we will hear no more. Scarlet Kate will become an important influence on Penelope's life in spit of only being a brief interlude. It was during this interlude that Lady Penelope achieved her sixteenth birthday. There was no such thing as a sweet 16 in those far off days certainly not if you were flying over the Indian Ocean trying to beat the monsoon to Serendib.

To while away the journey Kate would regale Penelope, who she now referred to as Penny, with tales of the brigands that plied their trade off the coast of Africa and who sometimes strayed North as far as the Malabar coast. Kate seemed very knowledgeable about the ways of these brigands and one in particular. A very merry fellow by the name of Harry Tempest. A man of hairy chest, a strong blackbeard and long pigtailed head. In fact a very hairy man all-round. You could see little of it but what skin showed was the colour of polished mahogany and matched the wooden leg he sometimes carried. No-one dare ask why he carried a wooden leg, let alone a mahogany one, as he had two perfectly good legs attached to his body down below. The eyepatch was another affectation and he never seemed to cover the same eye two days running.

One evening as the two ladies, rather one lady and one whose gentility might be less elevated, were finishing supper, a massive joint of pork from a flying pig. Kate let out a mighty belch and exclaimed that she had been fortunate to come across a flying pig whose captain would sell them such a joint. She almost let slip that whilst she had received the joint for the captain of the pig he had not received anything in the way of payment. Unless, of course you considered being allowed to live a little longer as fair recompense. Her tongue had been loosened somewhat by the excellent wine she had served with the meal to celebrate Penny's coming of age as it were. Penny, being under 18 was unaccustomed to alcohol and sensibly drank the smallest glass. Even so Penny was a little light headed and Kate much more so.

The table cleared and Kate's cigar smouldering in a solid gold ashtray she proceeded to launch into another entertaining tail of pirates, brigands and vagabonds. As she regaled her guest with outlandish tales she slowly sipped the wine and the cigar still smouldered. Kat never actually smoked but had learned from her father that there was nothing better after a good dinner than some good wine and a good Cuban cigar. By his definition of what made a good Cuban cigar Kate had decided that Burmese cigars were as good for the purpose and so the cigar smouldered on.

The level of wine in the bottle dropped ever lower and Kate's eyelids began to droop. Soon she was snoring loudly and would do so for the remainder of the night if previous occasions were any guide. Kate's crew on board the Beaten Bewitched consisted of a cabin boy, a cook and a helmsman who had once been a butler in the London residence of a well known aristocratic family who were not only well born but owned huge estates in Yorkshire as well as large mills in Lancashire and Rutland. They were also by chance neighbours to Penny's grandparents and some sort of distant cousins or great uncles, penny could never be bothered with all these family trees much other mother's despair. One day my girl, she would say, your are going to have to choose a husband and it best be from among your cousins or else you'll end up a pauper not able to afford a new wardrobe every year.
131.title: Lady Penelope Martin, A Young Lady of Breeding

choices: Find out more about this mystery man
133.content:
…looking for an assistant. Specifically, someone who can lift things much heavier than herself. Word on the street has been that there is a shipment coming tonight around the witchin' hour of three am. Penelope scouts the last dock in London and has come up empty handed each time. Taking out of her pocket, the steam goggles she uses to scout the area. She has made a few adjustments herself to make them work better. Using the technology of steam she has successfully created these goggles to see even further distances. Looking around at the men here the dock seems more promising. There are a few characters she recognizes and to work with someone she knows will be better than a stranger.

She first notices Big Red who she thought was dead. Interesting last time she seen him a mob of angry people in Tuscany were threatening to skin him alive and tar and feather him. One Eyed Pete is sitting on a bench eating a sandwich. Not surprised he does love his food. He blends in much better with the crowd with his ordinary brown hair and brown eyes. There is also another man Penelope is not familiar with that may be a good fit. Will have to investigate.

Object of the shipment tonight is if you can steal it is yours for the taking. Which man would you choose to help in this exciting adventure?
133.title: Miss Penelope Vanderbilt, Young Adventuress

1333.content:
The best way of solving a mystery is to go for it. Penelope walks up to this mystery man, looks up at him in the eye and says, "Where are you heading, stranger?"

The mystery man replies, "I am a vagabond with no where in particular to be."

A sailor not paying any attention about where he is going knocks Penelope to the ground. He grabs her arm and says, "Little lady, you can come with me. A little bit earlier for the ladies of the night to be out and about."

Jerking her hand back, Penelope stands defiantly stating, "I am no lady of the night. The reason I am down here is none of your concern."

The mystery man steps forward in front of Penelope, to tell the sailor, "My name is Rupert Silverton and this young lady is with me and our business is our business. Run along sailor, I am sure there is lots of work for you to do. Your day is not over just yet."

Rupert takes Penelope by the arm and the couple leave the dock. When they are out of ear shot of anyone, Rupert stops and says, "Woman, now explain yourself to me. I saved you back there and I deserve to know who you are. Since you know my name we can start with yours."

"I think we need to leave, now."

A constable is seen heading towards the couple.
1333.title: Find out more about this mystery man

choices: Reginald Warburton, A Young Gentleman on Holiday
Reginald Dolin Floyd, Opportunist and (Mad) Scientist
14.content:
A young man like Reggie certainly still had youthful adventuring dreams from time to time, but by one’s age of majority, certainly one should have grown out of such. Which certainly begged the question on that evening as to what he was doing in Cubitt Town, searching diligently around the warehouses for something of import. He made no mention of what it might be to bystanders, nor spent any time questioning them about it.

So what sort of man is our young Reggie? Actually, he is...
14.title: Reggie, A Young Man In His Twenties.

choices: He's already arranged a distraction for the dock boss.
He'll have to sneak around so the dock boss doesn't see him.
He's paid the man off, but not sure if he can trust him.
141.content:
Reginald had a different agenda than anybody about was likely to ever pursue. He was looking for a particular crate in amongst all the off-loads from his Uncle Richard.

He knew it was on the wharf already. In fact this was the only chance to find this crate. He had seen to it that the off-load was not known to anybody else. The harbor master was the easy part. This wharf was inland from the rest and the ship had already been passed to await its unshipping.

Of course, the dock boss was a different story.
141.title: Reginald Warburton, A Young Gentleman on Holiday

choices: The men kill the wharf boss...
The distraction becomes even more unruly...
The fight is quickly broken up by the wharf boss, and his responding guardsmen.
1411.content:
Reginald needed time to search through the crates, and because his ancient fossil of an uncle had lots of money he had a certain clout that he could use to make things happen, especially in "Merry old England." The wharf boss would be patrolling his rounds soon, and Reginald did not need anybody snooping around while he searched out his precious treasure...

He had taken some precautions, and 'they' should be arriving momentarily. He checked his pocket watch, compliments of his over-the-hill uncle. Almost twelve midnight, and right on time his hired help arrived. With that coming from the other direction a lantern light was swaying along near the ground. That was the wharf boss. The hooligans he had hired would be just the thing as the boss got close enough. Now he waited…

"Just a couple more minutes...," he thought to himself.

As the wharf boss neared the two men started arguing in a loud boisterous way, with one shouting at the other, "She was my first claim, you rude bastard!"

The other retorted, "yer bluddy cocked, ya ninny!"

The wharf boss picked up speed now coming at a good jog, and pulling his whistle out...
1411.title: Distracting the dock boss

choices: Wait at dock side to see what is coming
144.content:
Tonight was not merely an evening of merriment and leisure. These very docks, he hoped, held a clue as to where his "friend" had disappeared to. To call Mr Burke a friend was nonsense, but back stabbing loan shark was a bit too harsh as well. Mr Burke was to appear and help Mr Rourke with some real and some perceived debt from his many gambling endeavors.

Now his associate was a no show, which was hugely uncharacteristic when a buck was to be made. In between the damp musty clouds hugging the ground, a churning noise erupted from the ocean. Very feint, but definitely not made by natural means.

Reginald was certain it's wasn't merely a ship approaching either, as there was no steamy "chug" to denote any normal vessel. It was nearing in the evening fog... He decides to...
144.title: Reginald Rourke, Gambler

choices: Wait to see what happens next
1441.content:
Ducking below the pale orange lamp light of the docks, Reginald squinted out over the inky black waters listening to the swashing of the water with curiosity. Another ship nearby, a fishing schooner, began to bob in the water making the deck bell sound. Something drew nearer and two greenish eyes peeked from the mist. Twin brass lanterns with fierce copper green flame urged forward in the waters toward the docks, but there was no ship attached to them. Instead the lanterns were held aloft by two awkward poles jutting from the water like some great insectoid antennae.

A single staircase was above the water, the rest of the craft was below the rolling black and on either side two HUGE cork screws turned almost lazilly in the water making the chruning sound he'd heard earlier.

Two figures appeared from below and hurried onto the sodden docks glancing around very sharply. Both were dressed in red with black belts and sashes. One was a towering lady with black boots laced up past her knees. The other man was a fierce bald barrel chested man with HUGE mustache and piercing eyes.

Reginald should...
1441.title: Find a convenient hiding spot

choices: Go to the nearest tavern and ask about the foreigners
14411.content:
Russians coming to Cubitt at night in a stealthy craft? Reggie was a gambler, but not a fool. He waited until the two red suited Ruskies walked toward the dock master's shed and quickly Reggie made his leave. No sooner had he evaded around the nearest building, than he ran right into three white and gold suited men with long swords and tall jack boots. "Germans?" He said before he could stop himself.

The three men were clearly officers of high rank. They hurried into a carriage and the driver sped them away into the damp foggy evening. "What is going on?" Reginald knew there were events of great stakes afoot and when the stakes are high, there is ALSO a way to profit from it. He decides to...
14411.title: Retreat quietly

choices: Pose as an inventor to get in
144112.content:
Mr Burke's absence could only mean one thing, he had BIGGER stakes elsewhere. Going from building to building, Reggie ducked the Bobbis and checked the windows until he found the center of attention for the evening. The Black Wall Inn. There were guards at the door and the coach the German's had left the docks in.

Another vehicle approached, but it wasn't drawn by horses, it was a locomotive wagon belching black and then white as it approached. When the oddly dressed driver came to a rusty braked stop, a man in top hat and brass cane got out smiling as if this was the greatest day of his life.

"My GOOD sirs I DO hope you've reserved me a table? I'm Sir Arthur Phillips! Invenvent or and philanthropist!" He bowed to them still unable to wipe the huge smile from his face. The guards allowed him inside. Reginald had never seen a steam carriage like this one and knew the meeting happening inside was of great significance. He decides to...
144112.title: Find Mr Archibald Burke immediately

14412.content:
Hidden in the shadows, he watched the two red suited soldiers waiting impatiently for something.

Someone came down the rickety wooden stairs from a nearby building Reggie hadn't noticed. "SO! Have you brought my prize?" The approaching man in slender leather trench coat and cumbersome top hat held aloft his brass walking stick as he neared the two red suited visitors.

"Da, the vessel is in our posession, do YOU have the diagrams?" The tall red suited woman was Russian. Reginald recoiled from the idea of Russians making seedy deals on the docks... Yet they would not be here unless the deal was worth the trip.

The man in the top hat showed the inside of his trench coat had some techno scribbling inside it. In the pale green lanterns of the Russian water craft, things had taken on an eerie haze.

The tall woman shouted something in Russian and two more big burly men came from inside the rusted metal watercraft carrying what looked like a diving helmet on a gurnee. Yet something blue was glowing within the diving helmet.

Suddenly a shot rings out from a gun and Reginald...
14412.title: Wait to see what happens next

144122.content:
It's an ambush, yet Reginald's gambling nature makes him leap into action. The top hatted man has fired a shot at the Russians from that brass walking stick, and quickly draws a darringer to aim at their leader's face. "Time to walk away, while you still can!" He insists pushing the darringer's barrel closer to the tall Russian leader. She curses him in her native tongue.

And from behind him, Reginald had planted a heavy lead net weight to the back of the man's head. The top hat falls off revealing a strange crystal jutting from the top of his head. The Russians hurry to lift their odd gurnee and usher it back into their strange water craft. For long moments Reginald is stunned that the strange man has a glowing crystal jutting from his scull.

The tall valkry hurries to snatch his long trench coat off of him and leave the unconscious man face down on the sodden docks. Reginald finds his tongue and says...
144122.title: Decides to take action

1441222.content: After asking the man what was happening, Reginald received an answer. "Nothing of your business, young man. Now get going!" Without haste Reginald retreated from the docks back into a nearby town. Amidst the bustling city Reggie noticed a young man in mid thirties wearing fancy attire. He appeared to be speaking with a short, slender woman wearing a red dress. The two appeared to be arguing about something.
1441222.title: "What is going on?"

choices: A Daughter Of The Upper Class
A Shoddily Dressed Boy With A Leashed Animal
An Grimy, Oddly Dressed Girl Carrying A Large Bag
15.content: It all began at “The Screaming Cat”, a less than reputable establishment on Westferry Road. A new face seated at a table in the corner, a face quite out of place in the sleazy tavern, had every eye watching with curiosity.
15.title: A Teen Boy or Girl

151.content:
The girl at the table could only be described as out of her proper element. Her fine clothing almost glowed with vivid emerald and gold dyes, those latest wonders of chemistry. The steam carriage which had delivered her to this place, now guarded outside by its well-dressed driver, was a diamond in a coal bin next to the steam hackneys and horse-drawn wagons that trundled by. And the unusual handgun she had withdrawn from her bag and placed on the table when she sat down seemed almost too fancy to use on any of the denizens of this establishment.

-------

Which of the following three unlikely customers has wandered into the Screaming Cat?

1. Lady Lenore McGwinn, the granddaughter of a Scottish Laird.

2. Miss Audelia Amberton Wakefield, daughter of a wealthy American businessman.

3. Lady Camille Konoe (properly, Konoe Kameyo-jousan), ambassador’s daughter and scionness of one of the Five Regent House of the Japanese Empire, who is in England attending finishing school… when the school can hang on to her.
151.title: A Daughter Of The Upper Class

choices: Mr. Robert Angel Constantine, an opportunistic mineral explorer
Miss Samantha Jewel, a tinker mechanic
Father Johnathan Smith, an unconventional priest
1512.content:
Miss Wakefield, or Audie as she preferred to be known by her friends, caressed the large weapon gently. Most handguns were constructed of ordinary steel, which was then usually blued to provide some protection from corrosion. Her weapon, however, wasn't dark and blue like most of the handguns worn by patrons of the place. Hers was a brilliant steel gray. She was quite proud of this weapon, since it had been constructed from the finest crucible steel that was produced in one of her father's factories. The press had recently began calling this special steel stainless steel, although she knew that that was a slight misnomer. But, as long as it attracted attention, and, more importantly, business for her father's factories, she would allow the press to call it anything they desired.

The presence of the weapon actually served two purposes. The first was to attract attention to the steel being produced by her father's factories, located in North America. The second was to warn any rogue elements of the establishment that she was not to be trifled with.

Audie carefully scanned the crowd, looking for the person she was to meet here. All eyes, of course, were on her, for it was not often that such a spectacularly beautiful young lady entered such an establishment, especially one dressed in such finery, and double especially one packing such a weapon.
1512.title: Miss Audelia Amberton Wakefield

choices: It's a man, dressed in similarly posh clothing.
It's a boy, dressed poorly like the locals.
1513.content:
Lady Konoe sat quietly at the table, her hand resting on the grip of her handgun, an elegant weapon that used a powerful micro steam jet to fire off a ball of gaseous air. The pistol was entirely nonlethal as the 'bullet' of air was merely a method of knocking back attackers. It would only cause injuries like broken ribs at point blank range and no one was stupid enough to get that close right? Wrong.

A scruffy man who stank of alcohol walked over to her and simply grabbed her bag. He started rifling through the contents.
"And what are you doing?" She asked in perfect English. He ignored her and continued looking through until she raised the gun and fired straight into his chest. He was blasted back into the wall on the other side of the building and the bag landed on the ground where she retrieved it, ignoring the looks given by the locals. I'm only going to be here until he arrives anyways.

The door swung open and she turned to look at the person coming in.
1513.title: Armed and pretty dangerous

152.content:
About all the other patrons could say for certain was, he was definitely a foreigner. Although his English was excellent, his accent and his uniform were both quite exotic. And he was going to get the fight of his life from them if the serving girls didn’t stop paying almost exclusive attention to the handsome boy.

He did not seem to be there for such attention, however. The way he kept checking a remarkably complex looking pocket watch and scanning the pub with keen eyes, he was clearly waiting for someone. Who, from his manner, was apparently late.

----

Which dashing young gentleman has graced the Screaming Cat with his presence?

Pra’porchi Sergey Petrovich Gagarin - Teenaged junior officer of the Imperial Russian Navy. (Pra’porchi = Sublieutenant, or Lieutenant J.G.)

2. Sriram Jodha - Mysterious young South Asian teenager wearing a gold brocade sherwani and purple turban.

3. Dom Guálter Marinho - A son of aristocracy from the Empire of Brazil

Which dashing young gentleman has graced the Screaming Cat with his presence?
152.title: A Lad In Unfamiliar Uniform

choices: Sid And Curt Follow The Dandy And Waylay Him.
Sid And Curt Follow Him But Simply Observe.
1522.content:
"Check out yon foppish dandy," said Sideways Sid to his companion. "Likely he'll be carrying a handsome purse."

Curt tore his one good eye away from the serving wench. "Aye. Look at that long coat. Make a fine blanket." He gulped a third of his mug. "Where ya 'spose 'e's from?? Punjab??"

"Hardly. Prolly eastern India. Jharkhand or Odisha."

Curt nodded. "Aye. Dark skin but Caucasian features." The object of their conversation smiled as the waitress set a fresh mug in front of him. "Look at that! Bet 'e's got more teeth than everybody in this barroom put together."

Sid wondered which way the dandy would go when he left. If east, he'd go past the stables then a short stretch to the inn, where he was probably staying. They'd have to take him before he got there. And do it silently without rousing the horses or the sleepers. If he went west, though, it'd be a piece of cake. The apothecary and mercantile lay that way, but they were closed and shuttered this time of night. They'd drag his body into the alley and have plenty of time to find his money or whatever valuables he carried.

The raucous and festive tavern noise subsided as two men entered. They stood commandingly in the doorway, slowly looking over the crowd. Sid recognized the shorter of the two. He was Preacher Harris, owner of a sheep ranch a mile to the west. If he wasn't the richest man in town, he was darn close. He insisted his given name was "Preacher," but Sid doubted it. What kind of parents would stick their kid with an appellation like that??

The other, larger, man was a complete stranger, and was also the reason the crowd stared. Six foot-four, sandy brown hair trimmed in front, but falling to his collar in back. He wore boots with pointed toes, tough-looking trousers, a red plaid shirt, a leather vest, and a large, strange hat. Sid thought it was called a Stetson. Most striking of all: The stranger wore a holster belted to his right hip.

Curt's eyes grew wide as he took in the pistol resting in the holster. "Looks like one o' them 'Merican gunslingers," he whispered to Sid.

The two newcomers approached the table where the young dandy waited. He stood and shook hands with both of them, and they all sat. The waitress approached their table. The stranger said, "Whiskey." She looked hesitantly at Preacher Harris, who nodded. When she returned, Harris handed her a gold coin, and told her to keep the change.

Sid and Curt looked at each other. Preacher Harris was not exactly known as a big tipper. He was, in fact, the cheapest, most miserly miserable man the town had ever seen. He had just given the waitress enough to keep her child in milk for a month.

The crowd resumed it's merry carousing. Sid studied the three men at the nearby table. They spoke too softly to make out the words, but appeared to be in serious conversation. Whatever they discussed, it was soon settled. Harris and the gunslinger, if that's what he was, stood after just a couple of minutes and left without a backward glance.

The dandy watched them go. He seemed to let out a sigh, then took a sip from his mug. He waved the waitress away when she offered a refill. Sid thought he looked ... Deflated. Yeah, like he'd gotten smaller since his conversation.

"What're we gonna do??" whispered Curt. "We still gonna take him??" He licked his lips. "Like you said, he's bound to have a wad."

Sid looked at his Partner, then turned away. Could there be a more lucrative use of the dandy than simply killing him and taking his money??
1522.title: An Ominous Meeting.

choices: Guálter's father needs Curtis to help put an end to an uprising in Brazil.
Guálter's father needs Curtis to weaken Argentinian forces in Uruguay.
Guálter's father did not send him, Dom wants to be a pirate.
1523.content:
He placed his pocket watch back within his beige vest. Two women at the bar smiled and stared at him, he lifted his glass of water and returned the gesture. He could not afford distractions like women and alcohol. Especially not with whom he was dealing in that pub.

The door to the pub opened. The sound of metal on wood was the first thing he noticed. The smell of tobacco grew stronger, which he did not think was possible before it actually happened. And then there he was, the legendary Curtis Midgeley. The aluminum brace on his left leg crawled all the way to his hip, a chunk of his face where his left eye and cheekbone used to be was now a rusted iron patch and as he walked he put all three hundred pounds of his weight on his right leg.

He sat right across from Dom Guálter and smiled with what little teeth he had left. This was not the man Guálter was expecting. Curtis removed the cigar from his mouth and laid it in an ash tray on the table and yelled across the room, "Sweetheart! I'll take a good black stout if you've got one!" His voice was harsh and cut through all of the sounds of the crowded bar. "So, should we get down to business kid?"

Guálter smiled. "My father has sent me to get your 'assistance' for a problem we are having back home."

"My help? Don't know how much use I can be to your father in my current state." He said with a laugh and look at his left leg.

"May I ask how?"

"A bomb. Got scars on the hole left side of my body. At least I didn't lose my left arm." He smiled. "Always gotta look on the bright side of things kid."

"So you are the same man who has evaded His Majesty's forces for two dozen years?" Guálter asked the pirate.

"The one and the same. Your surprised?"

"No, I was just expecting-"

"Someone less battle scarred." He smiled. "Just because I've evaded the police for two decades does not mean that I have not had to fight my way out of some battles. Though I am a lover not a fighter, I will fight when it is needed." He slammed his fist on the table. "Now tell me about this job your father has for me. And where is my goddamn drink?"
1523.title: Dom Guálter Marinho

153.content:
The Screaming Cat was no stranger to female patrons, but they were normally average residents of the Isle of Dogs. The girl in the table at the back was notable equally for her singular comeliness, the neat press of her uniform and the saber hanging from her sash.

That uniform was in itself an oddity. His Imperial Majesty's services had admitted no women until very recently, so most Londoners were as yet unaccustomed to the idea, and few eyes in the pub likely recognized the one she wore.

----------
Kindly select your preferred heroine:

1. 2nd Lt. Donella Lindsey McIntyre - Duchess of Argyll's Own Flying Lancers. No surprise nobody recognizes her blue tunic with winged rocket insignia; sky cavalry is too new a development for most people to have even heard of it yet.

2. Engine Cadet Mbali - A lovely Zulu maiden. Her last name and her service affiliation are not known.

3. Ensign Grace Travis - Republic of Texas Air Corps. Odd to find her here, with no Texian airships in port.
153.title: A Lass In Unfamiliar Uniform

choices: The squadron of Texan air cruisers last seen bound for Antarctica.
A certain scientific programme in the West Texas desert.
The evil genius trying to create a war between their two nations.
1533.content:
Lieutenant Macleod did not want to approach the woman. She looked quite dangerous.

If it weren't for the officer's saber and the genuine insignia and devices on her uniform, one might be forgiven for seeing merely a buxom young redhead wearing a toothy smile and a stunningly tight sailor dress. Of course, the Republic of Texas Navy was the only fleet in the world whose uniform included a North American cattleman's hat and boots, so this officer and lady of its Air Corps would still stand out.

The lass needed none of it to attract attention though. The main thing that drew all eyes to her was her total lack of the composed character normally associated with female military officers. She was instead roaring in laughter at a lewd comment from a retired tar seated at the next table. Did she understand English properly? What that cad had just suggested she might do for him…

The empty pint on the table in front of Ensign Grace Travis probably had something to do with her behavior. Macleod hoped so, anyhow.

He gathered up his courage to approach her. No matter how perilous it felt to do so, a gentleman should be nearby to protect the inebriated lass's honor in case the old sailor tried to follow through on his proposition.

She cried out, "Hey, girl! Drag another beer over here! I'm powerful thirsty, y'know?"

As he arrived at her table, he noted the publican's head shaking in the background as he pulled a fresh pint for the bar maid.

The flame-haired Texan gave Angus a green-eyed head-to-toe appraisal. "Wahl now, here's a purdy buckaroo! Howdy there, pardner! An' who might you be?"

At least he was reasonably certain that's what she said. The last phrase sounded more like "Ann hoomah choo bee?"

"Madam, I am Second Lieutenant Angus Macleod of the Royal Marines. I'm inclined to believe you are the Ensign Travis I'm here to meet."

"LEFF-tenant, huh?" she echoed his pronunciation with a huge grin. "Well, Looey, yer inclined c'rrectly, ah reckon. Grace Travis, Ensign, Ree-public of Texas Naval Air Corps, atcher service. Why doncha pull up a log and squat?"

He wasn't sure if he had just been rudely insulted or invited to sit. He gambled on it being the latter, and took a chair across from her.

On closer inspection, he realized that if a proper British finishing school could have her for a year or two, she might become one of the loveliest creatures in this land. What misfortune, this loud voice and boisterous attitude!

A pint landed rather loudly next to her, shaking him from the trance the beauty had momentarily put him into. The bar maid was giving him a frown.

"What'll it be, sair?"

"Just a pint for me, thank you," he answered, a bit flustered by her cross stare. Had he done something wrong?

It wasn't him, he discovered. She turned her scowl on the redhead like a battleship rotating its main battery. "Barman is cuttin' y' off, what wiff dis bein' yer fiff pint. 'E wants y't'settle up now, while yer still conscious."

She was on her fifth pint? Macleod paled a bit at the thought, but cleared his throat. Totaling her five and his one, it would cost him a whole shilling, but the man she had been waiting for here ought to pay.

"Let him know that I will pay her account," he told the dash. "Please."

She trained her frown on him once more, for a moment, then went to fetch his drink.

"Wha that's rat gentlemanly of ya, sir," the ensign declared. "Thank ya kindly."

Rat gentlemanly? He shook his head, watching her guzzle great draughts of porter with gusto.

His own pint arrived while the Texan was explaining that she had met the grizzled mariner at the next table, apparently named 'Berkley', on the ship she'd crossed on. He'd been in New York visiting his daughter, and taken to drinking with her on his voyage home. When she'd asked about the location of this establishment where she was to meet Macleod, he'd led her to the place.

"How on Earth could you have finished four pints already?" Macleod demanded. "Didn't your ship only put in an hour ago?"

"Wahl, I hit dirt with nuthin' much to do, so I jes' moseyed straight over here. Figgered you'd be along soon enough."

He was too flabbergasted to respond to that, and hid his astonishment by taking another swig. It occurred to him, had she not even checked in to her lodgings yet? He saw the answer to that question; a medium-sized gladstone bag sat in the chair beside her.

Then he frowned. "You barely seem old enough to finish one pint. Aren't you a little young to be an officer?"

"Wahl that's rude! I'm nineteen, Looey!" She paused and admitted, "Next month." Then shrugged and added, "and a few weeks."

An eighteen year old drinking a half-gallon of porter?

He shook his head. "Well, we need to get a room arranged for you straight away. And we need to talk some business. You're attracting entirely too much attention here."

She tipped her head back and laughed, then looked him up and down, quirked her lips to one side and shook her head deliberately. "An' here I thought hiz majesty had sent me a dandy present. Ya got a ramrod up yer caboose jes like every Marine officer back in Galveston, doncha?"

He colored deep as the old sailor barked out a laugh, hiding his blush by taking yet another drink. If he stayed here in public with her too long, he'd end up needing to drink five pints himself.

And he needed to be sober to talk to her about the reason her admiralty had sent her here to England. Given her booming voice, they couldn't discuss it in a room full of other ears. After all, it was about…
1533.title: The Firecracker From Texas

choices: A British madman named Robert Falcon Scott hijacked the squadron to try it!
We think it may be part of a Brazilian plan to take over British Patagonia!
15331.content:
It took effort, but he did manage to coax the girl out of that establishment at last. He attributed the success more to the fact that she couldn't get another pint than to anything he did though.

He couldn't tell whether the look of reproach on the bar maid's face was her objection to the way that the ginger-haired wild woman was squeezing her plenitude into his arm as she clung to it, or if it were just her disapproval for his choice of female. Either way, she had entirely the wrong idea. His intentions weren't merely honorable, he was acting under direct orders of Admiralty!

He could understand why the dash would think that way though, considering how the drunk Texan ensign was behaving. He became more exceedingly aware of her ample chest the farther down the street they walked.

Judging by the driver's loose grin when they grabbed a steam hackney to leave the Isle of Dogs to a less problematic area, that young woman had precisely the same misunderstanding about his intent. He was glad her thick Cockney was more foreign to his Scots ear than the redhead's Texan. It prevented him from understanding more than a few words of the comments she made. He did understand enough to know it was somewhat ribald.

The lamplighter was still working his way down the street when they reached the nearest hotel that Lt. Macleod considered sufficiently reputable enough for a visiting officer of an allied navy. However, much to his frustration, the clerk would not consider letting a room to a clearly inebriated, unattached woman!

He encountered the same trouble at the next two hotels. The front desk clerk at the second of those positively glared down his large roman nose at Macleod in displeasure. He imagined the wink that Ensign Travis sent the man's way probably exacerbated that particular misunderstanding.

The ironic result of all this moral caution was that the lieutenant was forced to sneak a comely, nubile young woman into his own lodgings so she could sleep the alcohol off!

Fortunately, the girl at least heeded his urgent request to keep her voice down. He couldn't imagine what sort of mayhem she might have caused had any of the gentlemen in the adjoining rooms overheard a female voice that was clearly not the landlady in their male-only boarding house.

After he spent an uncomfortable night on the floor, using his greatcoat for bedding, he awoke to find an only slightly less lively lass putting the finishing touches on her uniform. Somehow, it was perfectly pressed, despite her antics the previous night.

Tying the bandanna around her neck seemed to involve as much care as donning his necktie. He stretched out the aching muscles in his back while he waited for her to finish using his mirror.

"Top o' the mornin', Looey!" she chirped to him in the mirror once she finished inspecting herself, which he immediately had to give a panicked shush. She just grinned at him, turned to set about tying his tie for him while asking in a slightly quieter voice, with a seductive tone and a pretty curl to her lips, "Now who might have helped me out of my uniform last night?"

His cheeks blazing as he remembered hastening to face the wall when she suddenly began disrobing, then having to mostly not look after he discovered he had to do something about the fact she hadn't quite managed to completely cover herself with the sheets.

He stared at the top of her head and stated in stiff tones, "I assure you, Ensign, you did that for yourself. I had my back turned until you were under the covers, and you woke first, so you saw where I slept."

He saw no need to mention the thing about the sheets, after all.

She grinned, finished and perched on the edge of the bed to pull on her boots. After a momentary bite of her lower lip and another teasing, eye-twinkling grin, she admitted, "Wahl, ah guess you bein' a proper gentleman an' all, I won't worry. And Mama teached me ah'd be bleedin' if you done anythin' ungentlemanly to me like that. Which I ain't, so seems like Daddy ain't got nothin' to worry about."

His cheeks were positively glowing red now. She finished by perching her hat on her head and tightening the chin strap. Leaning back on her hands, which uncomfortably emphasized that bosom and memories of the previous evening to him, she noted, "Besides, ah reckon we gotta talk now, 'bout our missin' Air Cruisers."

He cleared his throat and began searching for his officer's hat in order to have a different direction to look, while he clarified, "The ones that your government still are not willing to admit are missing."

The redhead grew a sour look on her face, complete with puckered lips, but she nodded.

"Which is why they sent an intelligence officer all the way from Texas rather than speak to us through regular channels via your embassy here," he added while taking a seat at the writing desk.

Another nod, but she grew a slight sheepish smile and scratched the back of her head. "Y'gonna jes' keep rubbin' my nose in our mess, or tell me whether yer government is willin' to help us look for them?"

He brushed a bit of lint off his officer's hat and studied it for other detritus. "Ensign Travis, they sent a lieutenant to meet with you. They did not send an adjutant to escort you to Admiralty. That should tell you that they are only willing to hear what you have to say. We still don't even understand what your cruiser squadron was intending to do. Surely your commanders don't think airships could reach the South Pole?"

Her lips pooched together as she considered her answer. Then she shrugged and tipped her head. "Well, no, normally they couldn't. Except… well, Daddy says it's possible, as long as it was the ships that we build in Texas. 'Cause we build 'em more rugged than most 'cause o' hurricanes and all."

"Daddy?" He had suddenly become concerned. If her father was an expert on airships... Surely Macleod had not just blithely allowed the daughter of the hero of the most recent Texan-Mexican war to spend the night in his bed?!

She looked very unhappy at this point as she nodded. "That'd be Admiral Travis. And y'see…"
15331.title: The Missing Air Cruiser squadron.

154.content:
One might argue that the boy himself might have been in his element, although the goggles around his neck and the smudges of soot on his worn, workmanlike clothing suggested he wasn’t working on the docks or newly off a ship. Perhaps he could have been apprenticed to a local steam livery, but would such work allow the beast he had walked in with?

----

Our urchin is one of the following three:

1. Angus B. McGloughlin - Scottish guttersnipe -- with his barbary ape Jock

2. Jeremy Rigby - Australian Aborigine wanderer -- accompanied by his dingo, Sheila

3. Aldo Lamberti - Italian tinker - and his pet raccoon Rogue
154.title: A Shoddily Dressed Boy With A Leashed Animal

1543.content:
Aldo was both a throwback and an enigma. He was an orphan who had been taken in by a brilliant but eccentric clock maker. Gillo Amarante was a modern day Leonardo Da Vinci, dabbling in art and inventing. Aldo had been his assistant earning room and board by doing odd jobs for Gillo. Aldo cooked and cleaned. Aldo kept the lamps supplied with oil and the fireplace supplied with coal. Aldo had also modeled for Gillo.

Aldo accompanied Gillo on the Alvington as it toured the Americas and Europe. Gillo had helped build the Alvington so everywhere Aldo looked, he saw cherubs with his face. Gillo had grown fond of the boy, even fatherly although Gillo would never admit it. Gillo never called Aldo son. Aldo was just an apprentice kept busy all day with various chores. However, Gillo would quietly look after the boy, teaching him and guiding him to a brighter future.

Gillo's fortunes fluctuated. He was never wealthy but he earned enough to give Aldo and himself a few nice things. It was while traveling in the Americas that Gillo rescued a raccoon from an angry farmer and gave the raccoon to Aldo. Aldo named the raccoon Rogue. Training a wild raccoon was difficult but Gillo helped.

Then one day while in London, a storm struck the Alvington a fatal blow. The Alvington sank in the Thames just near London Tower. Gillo and Aldo survived but Aldo got separated from Gillo. He searched for Gillo but no one in London had ever heard of the Italian man.

Aldo got a job as a hotel luggage carrier. He learned that the disaster of the Alvington may not have been completely an accident. A man by the name of Keane Digby was sought by Scotland Yard for suspicion of sabotage. Aldo remembered many conversations between Keane and Gillo. Keane often asked for details about the construction of the Alvington. Gillo didn't like Keane and didn't like all the questions Keane asked.

The disaster of the Alvington caused Aldo to think like a romantic and a naturalist. Aldo firmly believed "Technology will not improve life unless it is accompanied by improvements in the ethics of men." Aldo was torn up inside because he wanted to tinker with things like Gillo did but Aldo feared unethical men getting their hands on the machines Gillo made. Aldo longed for the simpler days of the Italian countryside where he and Gillo tinkered in innocence.
1543.title: Aldo Lamberti and Rogue

155.content:
The girl huddled at the table in the corner, munching on a simple meal and oblivious to the many curious stares. She’d not had a bath or a change of clothes for years, it seemed, and the clothing itself spoke of her origins far from the city.

--------

1. Lena Hiouchi - Tolowa (Native American) Maiden

2. Nguyen Hue - newcomer from French Indochina (Vietnam)

3. Molly Gallagher - Irish ragamuffin
155.title: An Grimy, Oddly Dressed Girl Carrying A Large Bag

info.brief_description: An Exhilarating Narrative Featuring The Technological Wonders Of Our Modern Age Of Steam!
info.description:
Herein we present tales of high adventure and technological wonder befitting our wondrous modern world of steam and science!

The setting for this novel is the present day, and by the present day of course we mean the opening years of the 20th century. Edward VII has ascended to the British Imperial throne after the passing of Queen Victoria, Mr. Roosevelt has assumed the American Presidency due to the untimely and most lamentable death of Mr. McKinley, and the amazing creations of the brilliant minds of such scientific luminaries as Mr. Tesla and Dr. Loveless have transfigured our world in astonishing and wondrous ways.

Our adventure sets forth from the Seat of Empire, the Shining Jewel on the Thames (Metaphorically. Between the fog and the coal smoke, not too much literally shining around here.) We meet our hero(ine) in the early evening among the docks of the Port of London.

Note that I will send GP for especially good entries. Don't expect them for short entries, but I have decided to begin rewarding serious writing.

--------------------------------


Refer to Chapter One for alternative history details and more important notes.

If you aren’t familiar with the steampunk genre, then think Jules Verne novels and the TV show/Movie “Wild Wild West”. Both are very close to steampunk (in fact, some people credit “Wild Wild West” as the first steampunk title.) Also, “League of Extraordinary Gentlemen” fits the bill. For the webcomic reader, see “Girl Genius”. For the Anime fan, “Sakura Wars” and “Steamboy” are both excellent examples of the genre.

Here’s a few links to help the steampunk newbie along:
http://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SteamPunk
http://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/SoYouWantTo/WriteASteampunkStory
http://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SteampunkIndex
http://steampunk.wonderhowto.com/

SCIENCE is a very important subject in Steam, but kindly toss those physics and chemistry textbooks. These are not the sciences you are looking for.

Think of me as the mod. I plan to enforce the 13+ rating. In other words, I will edit down anything I think has gone beyond it. Feel free to email me if you see any content that violates the rating.

Here is the WDC definition of 13+:

Recommended for Readers 13 Years and Older Only
This rating signifies that the content of this item is intended for readers 13 years of age and older and may be inappropriate for any minor under the age of 13. We recommend that supervising adults not allow such minors to read 13+ content. Horror and violence may exist at a moderate level, but not extreme. There may be mild references to sex, drugs or alcohol, but do not exceed mild levels. Mild swearing may be used, but no use of the harsher sexually derived words may be found, absolutely no completed F-word, or phonetic spellings of such words.

Take this seriously. As a parent, I care about these things.

I also may edit chapters which stray from the genre. If at all possible, I will not delete them, but will endeavor to recast them more in the steampunk vein.
